Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

PI: Hartman, Ryan L.
Institutions: University of Alabama Tuscaloosa
Proposal Number: 1264630
Title: Microreaction Engineering of Aqueous Phase Metal Catalyzed Reactions

Intellectual Merit

The use of water as a reaction solvent has the potential to impact the sustainable, continuous flow manufacturing of specialty chemicals. Successfully engineering such processes require the ability to overcome some challenges, including 1) management of the formation of solids as non-covalently bonded materials on reactor surfaces (e.g., scale deposition), 2) design of efficient catalysts using understanding of the fundamental mechanisms that govern synthetic transformations, 3) innovation of novel reactors that efficiently couple the aromatics that make-up intermediates in fine chemical production, and 4) integration of analytics with laboratory synthesis tools for online reaction discovery and optimization. This research will address each of these four challenges. The PIs plan the engineering and integration of microreactors with confocal Raman microscopy, where the intrinsic kinetic and mechanistic knowledge of palladium-catalyzed C-H functionalization reactions with hydrophilic ligands will be made available in the absence of transport limitations. The use of hydrophilic ligands, and hence water as a reaction solvent, in fine chemical manufacturing presents the opportunity for greener pathways to useful compounds. The PIs will combine reactor design principles, analytical chemistry, and synthetic methodologies aimed at developing a platform, which can be used to continuously synthesize fine chemical intermediates with water as a reaction solvent. The enabling technology will combine concepts of (i) microreactor technology, (ii) the design of hydrophilic ligands for synthetic organic reactions, (iii) non-invasive analytical techniques for reaction monitoring, and (iv) multi-step microchemical synthesis involving reactions and separations. If successful, the knowledge generated will foster a new paradigm of sustainable chemical process design: the use of water as a solvent to manufacture fine chemicals.

Broader Impacts

This research seeks to establish fundamental understanding of reactor and process design of synthetic pathways that utilize water as a solvent. This understanding will advance chemical processes that synthesize specialty chemicals, in a sustainable way. Undergraduate and graduate students will benefit from this work through the evolution of the reaction engineering curricula and undergraduate research opportunities for underrepresented groups. Furthermore, students K-12+ will be engaged by the creation of online YouTube videos through an undergraduate competition between the University of Southern California and the University of Alabama aimed at the interfacing of advanced chemistry and reactor design concepts, real world engineering problems, and pop culture. The work will also expose graduate students to international research experiences through collaboration with the Institute of Condensed Matter Chemistry Bordeaux (ICMCB). These educational components will strengthen the undergraduate engineering education at the University of Alabama, foster early interest in engineering careers from K-12 students, and provide unique opportunities for graduate students to gain international exposure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our investigation on the microreaction engineering of aqueous-phase metal catalyzed reactions made possible by the National Science Foundation generated unique intellectual merits.  The project lead to the discovery of the kinetics of an aqueous-phase catalyzed Cu-free Sonogashira coupling.  A possible switch in the reaction mechanism in the presence of water was also observed.  The knowledge could help design new ligands for the chemistry that enable the more efficient separation and the recycling of catalyst.  Another important discovery of this research is a new computational methodology for the estimation of the fraction of inactive palladium catalyst during the reaction.  The thermodynamics of palladium have yet to be coupled to this family of cross-couplings, and our results are an important first step in the life-cycle analysis of the catalyst.  Mathematical evaluation of liquid-liquid reacting interfaces also uncovered that mass transfer limitations may exist depending on the palladium and ligand concentrations, which are typically the most expensive components of the chemistry.  A switch in the governing principles that control the reaction was observed, which undergirds that chemists and chemical engineers should be working together to discover and develop new synthetic methodologies.  Estimation of the appropriate dimensionless quantities also showed that continuous-flow manufacture of the chemistry is theoretically more efficient than batch-wise processing.  Exactly how to design reactors for continuous-flow remained a mystery until the research generated a novel spectroscopic technique for the high-resolution analysis of immiscible interfaces.  Direct measurement of the data reported in journal publications was only thought to exist through molecular dynamics simulations.  The results infer that continuous-flow reactors that maximize the liquid-liquid interfacial contact area are the appropriate designs, while confined interfaces in microfluidic reactors can have a profound impact on the characteristics of the layers that make up the interfaces.

Our study also generated unique broader impacts in education and society.  The knowledge reported in journal publications could be applied by industry to design less wasteful and sustainable discovery and manufacture of useful materials, natural products, and pharmaceuticals.  The project also discovered new science and engineering that could advance undergraduate and graduate chemical engineering curriculums by introducing the concepts into courses.  Indeed, the funding has had a significant impact on education.  Two postdoctoral associates, two doctoral degree seeking candidates, and two undergraduate students were educated in organic synthetic chemistry and chemical engineering through research experiences made possible by the project.  A new laboratory was designed and built at New York University (“NYU”) in the Tandon School of Engineering that will provide physical resources to train future postdoctoral associates, graduate students, undergraduate researchers, K-12 students, and visiting scholars in the field of catalysis and reaction engineering.  The project also resulted in standardization of the way the laboratory collects and archives data for research collaboration.  The results have been disseminated worldwide through a variety of ways, including six journal publications (four featured in Reaction Chemistry & Engineering, Chemical Engineering & Technology, and Organic Process Research & Development, and one in preparation), fifteen conference presentations, twenty invited academic seminars, and six invited industry seminars.  Improvement in public knowledge of the research has been accomplished.  The work was featured at the NYU Alumni Day Dean's Luncheon where alumni, their spouses, and their children were provided the opportunity to learn about the research.  NYU Tandon Marketing and Communications have also broadcast news stories connected to the laboratory.  The laboratory also maintains a website and Twitter account (@HartmanLab) where news stories and journal publications of the results are posted on the world-wide-web/social media.  Finally, the research results were presented in the 2016 and 2017 NYU Tandon School of Engineering Research Expo where members of the Brooklyn community had the opportunity to learn about the project.
